content: The "Stealth Lobbyist Disclosure Act of 2007" requires certain coalitions and associations to disclose their lobbying activities. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 is amended to define a client as any person or entity that hires someone for compensation to conduct lobbying activities on their behalf. This includes coalitions and associations that employ lobbyists. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 defines a client as any person or entity that hires someone for compensation to conduct lobbying activities on their behalf. In the case of associations described in section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code, the association itself is treated as the client. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 defines a client as any person or entity that hires someone for compensation to conduct lobbying activities on their behalf. For associations described in section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code, the association itself is treated as the client, except for certain members. Members of a coalition or association contributing less than $1,000 per quarterly period towards influencing legislation are not required to be included in registration under section 4 of the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995. When a member of a coalition or association contributes over $1,000 in a quarterly period, they must be included in the registration under section 4 of the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995. When a coalition or association is considered a client under lobbying rules, they are treated as employing or retaining others for lobbying activities. Information on the coalition or association does not need to be included in registration under section 4 of the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995. The amendments made by this section apply to coalitions and associations listed on registration statements filed under section 4 of the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995, and those for whom any lobbying contact is made after the enactment of this Act. The amendments made by this Act require individuals listed on registration statements under section 4 of the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 to file a new registration statement within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Quarterly filing of lobbying disclosure reports is required under the amendments made by this Act, with individuals listed on registration statements needing to file a new registration statement within 30 days of the Act's enactment.
